moduleInfo.moduleTitle: Advanced Theory and Practices/10 Advanced Engagement Metrics/Percentage Completed Watch

overview.quote: To the algorithm, completion shows your video is actually highly satisfying.
overview.introText: While average watch time (retention) has been king, platforms now prioritize something even more meaningful - how many viewers actually finish your videos. This seemingly subtle shift can make or break your algorithmic performance.

keyTerms.definition: The percentage of viewers who watch your video all the way to the end.
How platforms gauge whether viewers felt their time was well-spent with your content.
The point where viewers leave your video, often when curiosity is satisfied or interest wanes.
When viewers feel they've received the value promised, leaving them satisfied with the experience.

actionPlan: Cut all fluff from the end of your videos
Identify your video's natural end point
Try a 90-second video length on TikTok
Aim for 33% completion rate as benchmark
Monitor platform differences in optimal length

mainContent.title: The Algorithm Shift
mainContent.text: Platforms realized that average watch time could be gamed with long videos that had early drop-offs. Now, they prioritize the percentage of people who watch to the end as a stronger signal of content quality.

summaryPoints: Can't be manipulated with video length

mainContent.title: The 33% Sweet Spot
mainContent.text: For videos between 80-170 seconds, aim for at least 33% of viewers completing the full video. This signals to algorithms that your content provides genuine satisfaction rather than initial curiosity followed by disappointment.

mainContent.title: Platform Length Strategies
mainContent.text: TikTok prefers videos over 60 seconds (with creator fund requiring 60+ seconds), while Instagram can reward ultra-short clips. YouTube Shorts sits somewhere in between, but all prioritize completion rates.

summaryPoints: Instagram: Can go as short as 5-15 seconds

mainContent.title: Ruthless Editing Strategy
mainContent.text: Cut your video at the exact moment your main point or punchline lands. Avoid thanking viewers, summarizing, or adding any content after the hook is satisfied - these all reduce completion rates significantly.

proTips.text: The ideal completion moment is almost mid-sentence of your conclusion - viewers stay to hear the end but don't get time to scroll away.
If your completed view rate drops below 20%, try removing the last 3-5 seconds of your video and see if performance improves.

finalWords.description: When viewers finish your videos, they leave with both satisfaction and curiosity for more.
